French PM Lecornu unveils broadly unchanged government
subhead: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu appointed a new finance minister and a replacement for himself as defense minister, but his new government is largely identical to the one that collapsed less than a month ago.

Republicans warn of pain ahead as US shutdown faces its second week
subhead: Most federal operations remain shuttered, with no signs of ending, as Republicans and Democrats continue to disagree about expiring Obamacare health subsidies. The country's last government shutdown in 2018 cost the US economy an estimated $11 billion.

title: The EAT-'Lancet' commission outlines a fairer global diet for feeding the planet sustainably
subhead: A study published on Friday in 'The Lancet' finds that food systems are a major driver of environmental degradation, rising chronic disease and growing inequality. The report calls for a shift toward less meat-heavy diets and a more equitable distribution of value along the food chain.

title: Sweden's new list of 'cultural values' sparks controversy
subhead: Pippi Longstocking, Ikea, Bergman… In early September, Sweden's conservative government unveiled a list aimed at defining a 'common frame of reference' to promote the integration of foreigners. The opposition has condemned the project's nostalgic vision.

title: The making of the Agnès b. cardigan
subhead: Since its creation in 1979, the Agnès b. snap cardigan has sold more than two million pieces. Functional and timeless, it has been produced in more than 150 colors and 40 versions, immortalized by world-renowned photographers and even exhibited in museums.

subhead: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban of sending drones over Ukraine, claiming they could benefit Russian interests.

title: AI's appetite for power could trigger electricity shortages in the US
subhead: Electricity demand in the US is projected to rise by 25% by 2030 due to the growing use of artificial intelligence. Yet, the power grid is struggling to keep pace, and most of the electricity consumed will continue to be generated from fossil fuels.

title: Why foreigners love France but struggle with the French
subhead: While France captivates with its culture and lifestyle, the French, frequently caricatured as arrogant and impolite, often have a poor reputation. This ambivalence raises questions about the roots of anti-French sentiment abroad.
